statement.p: In Astronomy, a unit of distance, called parsec (pc), is in common use. It is defined to be the distance at which an object of size 1 Astronomical Units (AU) (149.6\times10^6\ \text{km}) will subtend an angle of 1 arc-second, which is equal to 1/3600 of one degree. Two stars in a binary star system separated by 8.6 \times 10^{14}\ \text{m} are seen to subtend an angle of 0.2\ \text{arcsec}. How far away are the stars (a) in pc, and (b) in meters.

solution.p:
From the definition of parsec, we see that parsec is the value radius r in the formula
s = r \theta,
when \theta = 1\,\text{arcsec} and s = 1\, \text{AU} = 149.6\times10^6\ \text{km}. Let us express \text{arcsec} in radians.
1\,\text{arcsec} = \frac{1}{3600}\,\text{deg} = \frac{1}{3600} \times \frac{\pi}{180}\,\text{rad} = \frac{\pi}{648,000}\,\text{rad}.
Therefore,
1\,\text{pc} = \frac{s}{\theta} = \frac{149.6\times10^6\ \text{km}}{\frac{\pi}{648,000}\,\text{rad}} = 3.086\times 10^{13}\, \text{km}.
Now, the distance between the two stars is the new s value for which \theta = 0.2\,\text{arcsec}. Hence, the distance r to the stars will be
r = \frac{s}{\theta} = \frac{8.6 \times 10^{14}\ \text{m}}{0.2\,\text{arcsec}}.
Converting the arcsec to radian and carrying out the calculation gives us r in \text{km} to be
r = 8.87\times 10^{20}\,\text{m}.
This cae=n be converted to
r = \frac{8.87\times 10^{20}\,\text{m}}{3.086\times 10^{16}\, \text{m/pc}} = 2.87\times 10^4\,\text{pc}.

problem.title: Estimate Radius of Earth from Dip of Sail

sidebyside.p: A 2\text{-m} pole is attached to a boat. When the boat is 5\text{ km} away from the shore, you can see only tip of the pole. Use this information and assumption that Earth is a spherical ball to estimate the radius of earth.

solution.p:
From the geometry, you can identify a right-angled triangle with sides R, 5000\,\text{m}, and R + 2\,\text{m}. Hence, we can set up a Pythogora's equation and solve for R.
(R+2)^2 = R^2 + 5000^2.
This gives
R = \frac{25,000,000 - 4}{4} = 6.3\times 10^6\, \text{m}.

problem.title: Estimate Radius of Exploding Ball

statement.p: The British physicist G. I. Taylor argued that the radius R of a spherically symmetric nuclear explosion must depend on the energy E, the initial density of air \rho, and time t since explosion. Using dimensional analysis, find a formula for the radius at time t after the explosion. [Challenging problem]

hint.p: Express all quantities into their fundamental units.

answer.p: R^5=K E \rho^{-1}t^{2}, where K is a dimensionless constant.

solution.p:
Let us express the multiplicated relation as
R = K E^a \rho^b t^c,
where K is a dimensionless constant, which cannot be determined by a dimensional analysis. Now, we express each side into their fundamental dimensions. We drop the constant from this part.
\text{Left side} \amp = L^1 \text{Right side} \amp = \left( \frac{M L^2}{T^2} \right)^a \left( \frac{M}{L^3} \right)^b T^c = M^{a + b} L^{2a-3b} T^{-2a + c}
Now, equating the exponents of same unit/dimension on both sides (noting the missing unit on one side refers to the exponent of that unit being zero) we get
\amp a + b = 0 \amp 2a - 3b = 1 \amp -2a + c = 0
These are readily solved to yield
a = 1/5,\ b = -1/5,\ c = 2/5.
Hence,
R = K E^{1/5} \rho^{-1/5} t^{2/5}.
This is suggestive that we should look >R^5, which will give
R^5 = K'\, \frac{E}{\rho}\,t^2,
where K' is some domensionless constant.

problem.title: Predict Formula for Oscillation Frequency of a Star

statement.p: By dimensional analysis, find a formula for the oscillation frequency of a star of radius R and density \rho. Note that you will also need the dimensions of Newton's gravitational constant also, which is [G_N]=[L]^3[T]^{-2}[M]^{-1}. [Challenging problem]

hint.p: Express all quantities into their fundamental units.

solution.p:
We will assume a multiplicative relation such as
f = K G_N^a R^b \rho^c,
where K is an undetermined dimensionless constant. Now, the representations of the two sides in fundamental units gives (we ignore K in this step.)
T^{-1} \amp = \left( L^3T^{-2}M^{-1} \right)^a \times L^b \times \left( M L^{-3} \right)^c a\mp = L^{3a + b -3c} M^{-a + c} T^{-2a}
Therefore, we have
-2a = -1,\ -a + c = 0,\ 3a + b - 3c = 0.
These yield the following values.
a = c = 1/2, b = 0.
Hence,
f = K \sqrt{G_N \rho}.
